posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18934237
I got some from my bacon. I cut and slow-fry my bacon in rather thick slices and give them at least 40 minutes in total.
I have dabbled a bit lately with pork, and pork really takes time to taste well, and I far from eat it every week, yet I still save up the lard for perhaps some beef casseroles, like one with chili, beans, celery, onion and and green pepper. Chili casseroles with well-sizzled bacon is okay, but honestly, beef is better.The lard is well spent, however, with some tomato sauce, cumin, garlic and crushed black pepper.
So far it goes well with eggs, too, but mostly I use coconut, olive, sesame or butter for different stuff. I guess if I could keep the amount of lard down under one tenth in total I wouldn't mind it at all.

I had a feeling I would stick with bacon in regards to pork in general but lately I had to try the classics just to be sure I could make them.
Italian sausages with pork are tastty, but I can't really vibe that much with the usual nordic pork products besides perhaps the annual oktoberfest würst or another annual rib sandwich. It's so damn hard to digest, really.
Just a tiny bit lard in some recipes is delicious I think, but it's one fat I'd rather not overuse, just like sesame or cheap sunflower/rapeseed oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Accidentally shamed someone out of eating at my restaurant
posts.com:
I work at a relatively high end burger place whose entire gimmick is that you can basically customize these gourmet burgers any way that you want. The pay in tips is pretty damn good (~$85 a shift) because the customer base is largely older people who live in the exurbs of the city and come to get a drink or two at the bar. However, because it's also off the interstate, you get some weird ass people occasionally.

>One afternoon shift, a decently sized man walks in
>I seat him at his table and ask him what he wants
>He looks at the menu for a hot minute and looks at me with the most innocent look in his eyes and asks for a burger with EVERYTHING on it
>"Come again?"
>This dude literally wanted every single goddamn topping on the menu on his burger
>I already don't like this guy 'cause I think this is some dumb social media stunt, but I ring him up anyways 'cause it's my job
>I give him the total
>$50
>$50 for one fucking burger
>And if that wasn't enough, he asks for some cheesy fries on top of it
>That pisses me off the least
>It takes nearly half an hour just to prepare this monstrosity
>Finally ready, I bring it to his table and he begins gorging on this thing like there weren't several other tables around him in earshot
>As I'm tending to another table, I occasionally glance to see all the fucking toppings this guy got falling onto the plate and table as the structural integrity of the burger collapses
>He finishes up like normal and I'm thankful I don't have to see this dude again
>Halfway through my shift my manager calls me in and says that I'm gonna need to be relocated to another location because they're having staff shortages

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>I'm upset but they offer to pay for an Uber ride there because I didn't have a car at this time
>I arrive at the other one two hours later
>Working like normal
>The same fucking guy from two hours before walks into this location
>He gets seated and before he gets comfortable, he sees me and he immediately becomes uncomfortable
>I serve him again
>He orders the exact same fucking thing before but in a more nervous tone of voice
>Here I am again having to ring up another burger with fucking everything on it
>He eats it again once he gets just, just like before
>Getting fucking toppings everywhere
>He pays another $50 for the burger and leaves trying to make nobody notice him

This dude tried to go to another location just to avoid the embarrassment of ordering that shit at another restaurant only to see my stupid ass there witnessing his gorging ritual again. He was probably too paranoid to go to another location and do the same thing again because I would be there to witness him.

>>18940226
Yeah, at least here in California all food trucks are required to be "tied" to a sort of a hub where food inspectors regularly check on the conditions of the food trucks. I had a neighbor that worked at one of those "hubs" and she said that they're super adamant about like how clear the water has to be for mopping the floors, and the people that clean the trucks have to get certified to know how to clean properly from top to bottom.

Now, do ALL food trucks follow this rule?

NO. Especially in unincorporated Los Angeles County where it's perfectly legal to just set up a BBQ on any random sidewalk and just start grilling steaks or tacos (those are the best tacos you'll ever have btw.) The real secret is to see how many people are eating at that location. If there's a line, then it's all good, but if you're the only one there then I wouldn't touch it.

(Stay away from the seafood no matter what though).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18929116
it's not called like this in the netherlands. we just call it a "gietijzeren pan" which translates to "cast iron pan" but dutch technology is used to create them. this is the explanation.

In the seventeenth century, molds for making cast iron objects were developed in the Netherlands using a special sand mixture. The Englishman Abraham Darby became acquainted with this unknown technique in the Netherlands and introduced it to England. After much experimentation, he succeeded in making rock-solid cast iron pans. Because of the Dutch technique, these pans subsequently became known as Dutch Ovens. A name that has always remained.

Have a larger ceramic coated oval dutch oven and I keep it stored in my garage on my kitchenwares shelf. I bust it out for the following dishes:
Flamande
Brasato or any pot roast
Short ribs
Bolognese sauce
Whole or sectioned chicken dishes (not soups though)

Advantages are I've used it on all types of heat sources; natural gas hob and oven, propane grill, electric coil, glass-top electric, electric oven, etc.

Only drawback is that since there is a ceramic coating I can't use an immersion blender directly in the pot.

Le Creuset Dutch Ovens are the superior choice of material over Staub Dutch Ovens. They last for a long time and are far more reliable, so you don't have to worry about needing to buy a new one any time soon. The enameled interior prevents food from sticking, making it easier to clean and more versatile. All in all, they are the superior choice when it comes to Dutch Ovens.

posts.com:
>>18928639
I like an actual 4qt. I don't often need the size of a 5-6qt, and 3qt is indeed too small for the effort of making something that is literally only 1-2 servings.

Chili and any soup with beans really does well in it. This could be lentils or pasta faioli. It could be some a big pot of greens, a simple base of bacon and onions lining the bottom of the freshly rinsed mustards or collards. No sticking and no burning if you lose a moment of time in your busy cooking night. Creamy soups do better, like a potato soup, or a cheesy broccoli. I like to make a quick corn chowder, or a nearly quick pozole, and the hominy that sinks to the bottom stays unstuck.

Of course you will need a nice wooden spoon or silicone spoonula and a nice soft ladle to keep the ceramic lining nice. I love my staub silicone coated twin hardwood which is really a coated "spurtle" which is very versatile.

Expired ingredients, weevil infestations, poor sanitary conditionss and such are not uncommon.

That being said, I spent a month in juvenile as a kid, and I ate better than I ever did at home, though that's probably more a reflection on my mother than the quality of food served by the state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've went to jail a couple of times over a decade ago, never prison, and my longest "stint" was 4 days (former drug addict here, nothing crazy.) Also it was a comfy wipipo jail in the suburbs, not some inner city rape fest thank God. It all depends on your perspectives.

I'll put it like this. If you were given the choice between jail food and outside food, of course you'd choose outside food 8 days out of the week. Jail food sucked man, the portions are tiny, the food is underseasoned and all they give you are some tiny salt and pepper packets that are about the size of your thumb nail. Crispy things are soft, soft things are rock hard, hot things are cold and cold things are suspiciously warm. I mean what are you expecting, it's fucking jail, not a 5 star resort.

That being said, when you've been in jail for 16 hours and it's become abundantly clear that you're not getting out any time soon, a plate of lukewarm goyslop doesn't sound too bad. I got "lucky" during one of my trips to jail and I got to eat one of the bi-monthly hot breakfasts (normally it's cereal). Two tiny sausage patties, two tiny pancakes, a tiny syrup packet and no butter, one single limp dick slice of bacon and a fruit cup. Sounds like garbage to you. But for someone who hadn't eaten all day because I got arrested in the middle of the night, it was actually a pretty good meal. Oh yeah, and an acceptable side dish in jail is a half a slice of disgusting wheat bread. I got that shit during every single meal. It was gross.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937504
Commissary isn't much better, but again it can be serviceable if you're really hungry/looking for taste of home. I only had a commissary card one time during my few visits, and one look at the menu told me it was a total rip off. Things that should be paltry like bags of chips, pickles, hot sauce, tuna, and ramen were like 5x their outside price. Headphones and calling cards were like 10x a reasonable outside price. Just another way to extract money from people in jail.

I did try jail cuisine one single time, but it was wasted on me. I was detoxing/withdrawing from drugs when one of the guys in my block who coincidentally went to the same college I did cooked up some kind of jail house burrito. I remember him breaking up some bags of ramen and cheetos into a powder and mixing it with nacho cheese and hot sauce and chopped up pepperoni sticks. Since I was dope sick at the time, all I needed as a wiff of that bullshit and it was enough to make me gag, and it wasn't much better going down either. I only ate a few bites of my burrito before throwing it out. Looking back, that was such a dick move. That guy didn't have to spend his hard earned jail money and waste his time crafting a jail burrito for me, but he did, and I didn't even have the curtosey to finish it. Kinda a weird thing to think about when it comes to jail but it's one of the more interesting things that happened to me in there. Otherwise we mostly watched TV and talked shit.

The first meal after you're released does empirically taste better than it would otherwise though. A fucking baconator and spicy nuggets from Wendy's never tasted so good brehs. It tasted like freedom.

Luckliy I haven't been back there in many years, but I can't assume it's gotten any better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937179
People generally use "acidic" to convey a pleasant sourness, and "sour" to mean a harsher unpleasant sourness. Acidic coffee is valued quite highly by some people, but it's a preference thing.
Unpleasant sourness usually comes from underextracting coffee, whereas excessive bitterness comes from overextraction. You can have coffee that has neither of these really and is just sort of sweet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937179
There are different acids and quality of sourness. Acetic acid is generally garbage because it feels like drinking hot vinegar. Something like malic acid is nice and what I describe in making a “crisp” cup, that give it a light tang to it like a green apple and pair well with fruity notes, just feels tasty and light. I don’t remember all the shit, but probably learned about it in a hoffmeme video. Generally lighter roast can be more acidic. Does it kind of fuck your throat too with the after taste? Sourness/bitterness can also result from fucking up the brew. Then again, some folks I know just can’t tolerate any sourness period, it’s all preferences.

Is overextraction the same as increasing the ratio?

>>18937310
cool

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937531
No, although ratio can effect it a bit.
Extraction depends primarily on these factors:
>temperature (higher temp = higher extraction)
>how darkly roasted the beans are (darker = higher extraction)
>time (longer = higher extraction)
>grind size (finer = higher extraction)
To a lesser extent it's also effected by the amount of water used, if you use little water it's not going to extract as much, but if you use enough water it extracts more. But that's probably not a factor in most cases unless you're brewing with like an aeropress using the original recipe for it (which has very little water)

Good day /ck/,

I'm attempting to make bagels for the first time. I was thinking of using an overnight autolyse to help develop some of the gluten, but since bagel dough is lower hydration (aiming for 55%) it probably wouldn't autolyse too well if I use all the flour.

Total I will use 1910g flour and 1050g water, this will give me 54.97% hydration. I'd like to leave out 500g of total flour so the dough can autolyse better. This would be: 1410g flour and 1050g water, giving a 74.47% hydration autolysis. I'll let it autolyse overnight in the fridge, then knead in the remaining 500g of flour, then overnight again to bulk ferment in the fridge. Also I'm using a poolish (200g/200g) so the autolyse will be fermenting too.

Will I encounter any major issues trying to do it like this? Should I just knead in all the flour at once instead?

Chinchilla unrelated.

>>18938271

Polishing is supposed to make your 2500 edge last a tad longer. Since a knife's edge is basically made of a lot of pointy spikes, a grit past 2000 makes them smaller and thus hold their shape better. They will just be more efficient longer by just using a strop or one of those honing rods, which straighten the spikes that gent bent (but not dulled) after use. Chefs would probably sharpen their knifes around every 2 to 3 weeks but these guys go theough literal tons of vegetables and meats per month and also need something that is razor sharp all the time. Meaning you could easily stay a few months without any sharpening as long as you regulary strop

>>18939063
I find it to be the defacto test to measure sharpness and edge refinement. After doing the finger nail test 1000 times you can judge how sharp a knife pretty easily.

Just to be clear what I'm talking about is how much force it takes to have the edge stick on your nail.

Once you have a great way to measure sharpness you can understand what is working and what is not working to improve your edge.

I have very expensive and hard steel knives, so it would be sinful to use a pull through. Regardless is takes me about 2 minutes on a 1500 grit stone to get shaving sharp from a knife that needs a tune up.

>>18939972
>1500 will get shaving with skill

this is true. i went so far down the sharpening rabbit hole a few years back that I got into straight razors. if you are going to sharpen a straight razor that you intend to shave with, you should be able to do 20 passes per side on a low grit stone (400-600) and have it cutting hair afterwards. otherwise, you aren't good at sharpening, and you should work on your technique.

of course, quality straight razors don't require a steady hand to hold an angle. you literally just lay one side flat on the stone, do your strokes, and then flip & repeat. the key is to use the same pressure for each side.

>my blade can shave with no irritation at 1200 but can't at 6000
>what am I doing wrong, master?

that's too big of a jump in grit size. never jump more than 2.5x in grit size. doing so will take much more time for the smaller grit size to actually be effective at reducing groove size. the same concept shows up in sanding wood.

Caffeine doesn't wake you up. It simply fills brain receptors that would normally accept the hormone that sends you to sleep. Normally after naturally waking up there are still some hormones in your blood which encourage you to stay asleep, caffeine stops that hormone from being able to tell your brain "stay asleep" or "go back to sleep".

Again, caffeine doesn't wake anyone up and those who think that are just drug addicts. if you cannot start your day or you go through withdraw in the afternoon without a few cans of monster or whatever it means you've made yourself addicted to a substance that doesn't actually help you function. Most people are pussies and don't want to go through the week of detox to get off caffeine.

Reminder, it has a halflife of about 8 hours in your system. If you have shitty sleep its because you're preventing your brain and hormones from working normally. Drug. Addicts.

>>18938827
Bro I'm a little bit of a hypocrite; I drink about 3 cups of coffee or tea in the morning because I like the taste, the ritual of preparing the water, french press, pot, cup, and honey or whatever. I definitely do not NEED caffeine as I also drink caffeine free coffee and teas about half the time.

But its more dependent on you personally and how your day goes. I have a caffeine sensitivity and if I made a really strong pot of tea and I finish drinking it at noon, sometimes I just cannot get to sleep until 1 or 2am. if I watch it and I'm careful and make a normal to week pot and finish drinking by 10 while drinking plenty of water throughout the day I'm fine. I also get to sleep a little better if I just don't drink any for the day. That said, caffeine doesn't help anyone sleep better so stopping "too early" is much better than stopping too late. Some people get really pissy because of their caffeine withdrawal symptoms too. Again, thats because they're a drug addict. The approximate halflife is 8 hours, meaning if you stop at 3, its like me drinking a single cup of coffee at 6pm. If you ever noticed your sleep isn't great, its because your brain isn't actually sleeping because of the caffeine. Try stopping at 10am and switch to anything decaf after that. I think even decaf coffee is a diuretic and dehydrates you, I know anything with "energy" like decaf monster or whatever also dehydrates you. Dehydrated brains also don't sleep well.

Just do an experiment for a solid week and try to notice the differences in your mood and sleep after 7 days. Stop caffeine at like 10am and don't drink any on the weekends. worst that happens is the first couple days feel weird but after that your body and brain adjust to less caffeine.

I got one of those Zojirushi Japanese rice cookers and it's become one of my favorite kitchen items.

There's the obvious benefits:
Rice is always cooked perfect, better than I do in a pot, it's easier, I can't mess it up, and the cleanup is easier.

But the really big one that you don't realize until you have one is that it's fire and forget. Before you start cooking you load it up and start it and you never have to worry about the rice again until you need it. This thing cooks the rice perfect by itself and then can keep it warm and at perfect consistency for over 12 fucking hours. When you need the rice you just open it up and scoop it out.

Also it plays twinkle twinkle little star to let me know when the rice is done. (Japan you silly.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18938087
Food is a complex market in that there are multiple different sources as well as different suppliers of the same nutrients. So protein sources like eggs compete not just between suppliers, but also against beans, chicken, pork, beef, etc.

If your unit costs gets too high, people can swap to alternate protein sources. Additionally, high prices allow competitors to enter the market and undercut you, especially if they deliver similar quality. Keep in mind that food SPOILS, so you can't just sit on the eggs for months and sell them when demand ticks up later. Food made now needs to be processed and sold with a quick turnaround. So that means if you overproduce, you literally lose money.

This is why you get price reduction on food items where you would not see it for something inedible and shelf stable, like a battery for example. That battery is good for years, and there are only 2-3 makers for batteries. So you can "collude" a little bit to ensure prices stay level, and no one can really make batteries without massive investment in a factory. Good luck doing that with food where suppliers literally span countries and nations, and every Tom, Dick, and Harry with land and chickens can get in on your market.

>>18934548
>Fast food
I guess it depends on how upscale the place is (never been to Fatburger myself), but a tip in a fast food place is very much appreciated, but not expected. If you routinely tip, and the staff get to know you, you might get some freebies, but all-in-all you should expect the same basic quality of food and service.

>Restaurants
If you become "He who does not tip" there is a chance that service will tell BOH "Take your time, it's just _". BOH might not even share in the tips, and even if they do, they might not care. You will probably get the same quality of food, but maybe not the same quality of service.

>Bar
You go to the back of the line. If the server or bartender knows that you tip well, they usually won't risk losing that to take care of two people who they know don't tip. They'll still work the room/bar, and unless you're a total twat, you'll still get served, but you shouldn't expect to ever cut the line if you're a notorious cheapass, and if it's a rougher kind of place, bringing poor service to light might get you called out.

>>18939093
In the US, nobody ever makes less than minimum wage, not even tipped positions. If a tipped employee makes less than minimum wage (counting total number of tips divided by hours worked) the employer is legally required to make up the difference. I'm not sure why they let you children and retards even make this argument without knowing the basic facts about the law.

In countries where there's no tipping, patrons still pay the same amount, the extra just gets paid to the restaurant before it's doled out to the employee rather than going directly to the employee. I'm not sure how you can possibly be so retarded as not to understand this. Service workers in Europe do not make more money in total than they do in the US. In fact, they make less. Restaurant owners also make less. People eat out less, because restaurants are more expensive. Everyone is poorer in real terms. Europeans can't afford cars, houses, air conditioners, full sized refrigerators, dryers, or many other luxury goods that we take for granted in the United States. They don't eat out every day like most Americans do, because they can't afford it. Americans can afford to go to restaurants every day, and waiters in America can own houses. Neither is the case in Europe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tipping is a form of price discrimination. Much like coupons, it allows the poor and stingy to pay less, while the rich and generous can pay more, for the same product. This lowers the average price of the product, increases the pay for employees, increases the profit for the owner, and enables more consumers to purchase the product at a price they find agreeable. Tipping makes the economy more efficient and literally benefits everyone. If you've never taken an economics class, please Google "price discrimination" and if you have a 3-digit IQ you will thereafter understand why tipping is good.

Most people who are against tipping only think this way because they think tipping results in servers getting less money, and/or customers paying more money. Neither of which is true. Compare wages and restaurant costs in the US and Europe to find out that it's literally the opposite. American servers make on average about double the salary of European servers, but our restaurants are simultaneously cheaper. You can also just look at what happens to all the tipless restaurants they've tried to open in New York and California. Nobody wants to work there, the bills are expensive, and they always fail.

The real reason that (academics) came up with the idea that tipping is bad is because it was proven that black servers make less tips than white servers, and black customers receive worse service than white customers because they tip less. The entire discourse about tipping was started because tipping is racist, and you people talking about wages took the bait. They can't allow any institution to exist which allows haggling, flexible prices, palm greasing, winking, or nudging, because these institutions benefit the many at the expense of the black. The same people who want to eliminate tipping also want to make it so that cops can't let you off with a warning, cars at dealerships are a fixed price, salaries must be published publicly in job postings and can't be negotiated, etc.

You are arguing that tipping is akin to what's called a progressive tax on wealth (as opposed to regressive). This would be true if I weren't physically blocked from leaving the cheapest restaurant in the neighborhood by the waiter/asst. manager/son of the owner for leaving a 12% tip on two dissatisfying entrees instead of 18%+. Yes, this happened. He berated me, demanding I explain every detail of what I didn't like about my and my friend's food -- it honestly seemed like that scene in Menu everyone's posting if only this guy had the least bit of competence to justify his attitude.

From everything I've heard from stories from literally everyone in the U.S., this is a more common kind of experience than not nowadays -- being blocked and/or harassed for an insufficient tip -- and it is definitely more common in cheaper restaurants. Thus the wealthy who frequent upper class restaurants can still be stingy and not be publicly harassed, while the poorer who can't even afford the base price of such restaurants will not find themselves in an establishment that will allow them realistically not to tip.

Thus it is not in any way analogous to a progressive wealth tax that you describe, and if anything will be regressive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
sipping on some of "That Camphor Cake" from LP
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1188363800/that-camphor-cake-400g
It is a aged white label production sheng cake made sometime in the late 1990's to very early 2000's. Very gnarly looking, lots of stems and large misshapen leaves but the tea is undoubtedly well aged. The cake is aptly titled, camphor is its dominant flavor. Reminds me of moth balls and aromatic cedar with earthy and medicinal undertones. Gives me nostalgic vibes of playing in my grandparents wardrobe as a kid. I was not so sure about this tea the first time I had it, but it seems to have grown on me. Definitely, not an everyday drinker or a tea for everyone but I appreciate having it in my stash.

Thinking of stacking up on my favorite loose tea, some nepalese second flush Kanchanjangha. It somehow struck me. I can only imagine with the quality of the zip-lock the tea can still be considered good decades to come.
Question: Any diehards have a strong opinion against any 30sec->1min soaking? I use a metal strainer and rarely let it pass the two minute mark. I can enjoy a trifle strong assam as well, but rarely divert from this incredibly light, floral and mild nepalese variant I never have fund myself infusing more than once and never diverted from using water still boiling in the kettle. Do you think I'm missing out on something? I have incredibly hard, unfluorinated, tap water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18931036
More than anything you should try and soften your tap water somehow, hard water really mutes the flavor of tea.
Short infusions like that are okay but you might as well brew the same leaves twice or even 3 times if you want to do that.
First brew 1 minute or so, second two minutes, third four minutes (if it's worth doing)
The later brews won't taste the same but you are missing out by brewing the leaves for a short amout of time.
If you want to decide if you think its worth getting some kind of water filter to deal with the hard water buy a gallon of cheap spring water (poland springs is good for this) and try brewing your tea with it to see what the difference in taste is.
I also have really hard water and i got a filter pitcher from pur and that helps a lot, britta ones also work fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18935710
First off, those sha qing videos are very relaxing to watch. Second, although I think I disagree with William's definition of "snob" and "snobbery," the class of hobbyist he's describing definitely exists. He cleanly defines a line between the two. An elite may have difficulty identifying he is in the elite when the snob acts like an elite better than he can. He draws some understandable parallels to other fields, military and science that I also found enlightening.
However my favorite part of the video is how bloody well he articulates the necessity of a an objective hierarchy existing in the gamut of a product-based hobby. To not be elitist, as defined at the start of the video, is to not show passion and you might as well be drinking grocery store bags. Or worse yet, one might not have that passion and still have the desire to belong to this community of hobbyists, also known the arrogant snob.
There was also some great little snippets of hierarchy of understanding of tea and thinking about sha qing or tea in general as having layers of abstraction to understand. Darn insightful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18935823
Puer teabags can be surprisingly decent in my experience.
Use boiling water, put the teabag in the mug and put an inch or two of water in and dunk the teabag and swirl the water around for like 15 seconds. Then dump out that water and fill the mug normally with the teabag in it. Brew 5 minutes at least or just leave the teabag in and drink when it's cooled off enough. It's definitely a different flavor then any tea you might be used to. Exect chocolate, woody mellow flavors. It usually tastes better then it smells

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
www.chinaheritagequarterly.org/features.php?searchterm=029_life.inc&issue=029

I pretty much agree, the general vibe in a lot of hobbies is a sort of intellectual nihilism, centered around the trend of anti-gatekeeping. The central desire is to go to the metaphorical buddhist monastery, and to be told that you are already enlightened, that you were always enlightened and that you just need to realize it. Not the reality, that you will be told that you will be spending the next twenty years of your life at least meditating and studying scripture, and maybe then you will become enlightened along the way some time later. 4chan does well both in killing snobbery, there's no face I have to present to this thread, I have no status or persona here so fighting over it or trying to build my status is pointless; and in promoting the necessarily somewhat violent discussion. No one's posts are put above another, there is no system of upvotes or likes to support a rebellion of the underclass, or the anti-enthusiasts. If you have a strong opinion about tea, you have to lay out your argument and be judged on its merits. Almost especially for tea, I think that this format emphasizes the "jianghu" of tea. There really are not clear lines, everyone has their own extremely strong opinion of what tea is, and you can make very compelling arguments for pretty much any of them. Part of tea culture, at least enthusiast culture, is almost as much arguing about tea as it is drinking tea. Forming an opinion, developing it, and then presenting it passionately is part of the fun. I think it's especially enjoyable without the sort of nonsense that comes with forums, and communities that promote snobbery.

Most sources say 5-10mg caffeine per g yerba or around 400mg caffeine per 50g gourd.
I'm not too concerned with exact numbers cuz 100mg after a week break != 100mg for the 4th time that day.

But you generally put a liter of water through 50g of yerba cuz that's how long the flavor lasts.
1 cup of coffee requires around 14g coffee and a liter is around 4.25 cups so coffee and yerba are pretty evenly matched.

Tea has around twice as much caffeine per g but it makes around 4x more liquid in terms of flavor. (pulled the 4x number from ass)

Okay, this review may dissapoint some, but it has been a while since I have had puerh. I'm going to have another session with a different ripe puerh to get a little perspective.

Aroma of the tea lid was quite strong. Third and fourth brewings the typical forest floor aroma came out more, but it was subdued. Exotic wood, old books, incense. I liken it to stumbling across a temple in the rainforest made of exotic woods that had old scrolls and incense within.

Taste: nicely sweet and creamy mouthfeel, the typical puerh taste was subdued somewhat and that incense and woodsy flavor is present with maybe some dried fruit along with it. Had about 6 or 7 brewings.

I really enjoyed it.

>>18939716
I don't have a huge amount of info about it, Puerh Caravans and Urban Chic is as always a good overview. I've actually been meaning to do some semi-serious research about exactly this topic and compile a small sort of overview of the time, since it was so formative in terms of the state of modern puerh. There's a few fairly authoritative and contradictory sources, so I'm not sure how well it will go, but I think it's worth doing a 1990-2010 overview of puerh.
http://www.marshaln.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Yu-The-Authentic-Taste-of-Puer-Tea-and-Transnational-Interests.pdf
This touches on it too, more about the differences between aged sheng and shou but it's worth throwing in the reading list at least as a background perspective to the market forces involved.

>>18933978
Japan has some of the weirdest and most hilariously bad dishes out there. From the nearly inedible raw fish dishes to the absurdly funky flavors of seaweed and fermented fish, Japan's cuisine can often leave one in a state of disbelief. Japan's predilection for creating unusual dishes is truly unmatched, and often the end result is a meal filled with slapstick ingredients, ill-advised pairing, and experimental flavors that in no way add up. If you're up for an adventure and you don't have a funny bone, Japanese cuisine might be for you.

greetings, barbarians
(for those who don't know, "barbarian" comes from the greek "βάρβαρος", literally meaning "someone who doesn't speak greek". no, really, check wikipedia)

i am greek.
please, stop lining up to suck my dick.
it gets tiring after a while.

i will not presume to be qualified to objectively judge the quality of each countries cuisine
im not sure that is even possible, given that taste is subjective
what i can say, with resolute certainty is this:

-greece has by far the best takeout/delivery in the world
yes, really. i've traveled a lot, i've had to eat out a lot
a shitty greek takeout is as good as some of the best takeout you could find in any other country
good greek takeout will mog anything short of a really fancy restaurant

-good greek tavernas are GOD tier. i know many of you haven't had the pleasure, since you won't find any of them in the common touristy places. but trust me, if you know where to go, it is fucking divine. i've had meals in $500/person restaurants, and they didn't come close. fancier, yes. paired with much better wine, sure. but the food still was not up to par. no faggoty ass chef can even hope to compare with a greek γιαγιά who has been cooking the same potatoes, from the same field,in the same kitchen with the same pan for the last 40 years. its just not possible. sorry.

so go to greece for a vacation. make some local friends (buy them drinks), and ask them where they like to go to eat out. when the waiter comes, just ask for whatever is popular. leave a large tip

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>hur dur UK food bad
I've been to the UK. The cities are so full of variety that to say there is 'British food' is just dumb
>b-b-but fish and chips and look haha look at this meme local dish they eat this xDDD
No. They don't. Some local people might. But you don't go into a random restaurant and see their meme shit just like you don't see Scandinavian pickled fish in places. Furthermore, if you actually research 'British' food you'll see certain shit you didn't expect to be theirs. Hamburgers, for example, were first mentioned in an English recipe book. 'American as Apple Pie'? Nope. Potato chips? Oh those are British (despite the urban myth meme about sliced potatoes and the angry chef). Even fucking lasagna is based on an English dish called loseyn.

It's just a shitty meme based on Americans who went over to a starving Britain during WW2 and saw they were making do with whatever they could get and didn't waste shit. Same as 'Brits have bad teeth' when if you actually google that shit, you find they are the 4th or 5th healthiest in the world. Why? Because they get free dental healthcare. They didn't in WW2.

Memes =! Reality. But, as I said, the UK doesn't have 'English/British Food' restaurants. The closest are basically diners where they'll do English Breakfasts (but all day). There is no 'This is an English restaurant fellas'. Nearly everything is 'fusion' over there. One place I went to had American shit on it that fused with British stuff. It was amazing. Went to a Lebanese place which did authentic shit and some 'fusion' stuff, basically I asked it was just stuff customers asked for, so slightly spicier versions of common Lebanese dishes.

It's like thinking the French came up with all their cuisine when they stole half it from Italy and half of it from the English who used to control parts of France.

No idea what 'Aussie Cuisine' is so you got me there.

What are your favorite recipes for scratch Lasagna?
Im not too worried whether its true authentic or not, I just want to try and make my own sauce/filling and my own pasta. I did already buy Ricotta and Italian sausage because I was looking at some "easy" recipes with canned sauce and premade pasta sheets.

I own a pasta roller ive never tried out, and figure if Im going through this effort already why not actually make it from scratch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
a good ratio for scratch lasagna noodles is 2 parts flour and 1 part (cracked) egg by weight. And generously salt your fresh pasta dough because fresh pasta, already containing lots of moisture, won't absorb as much salted water as dry pasta does, so the mixing stage is the best time to salt the pasta dough.

For sauce and other fillings I don't follow any recipe but my own, but in general I think all beef gets you the best flavor. For veggies in the sauce I usually only add onions or shallots, but carrots would taste good in there too if you like.
and any canned tomatoes (crushed, whole peeled, puree) are the best as long as the can doesn't list "tomato juice" or "calcium chloride" in the ingredients on the back label because either or those ingredients listed means the product will have a bitter shitty taste. No, you do not have to get fucking san marzano tomatoes. They are good but not like the only good option there is.
For seasonings of the sauce i like salt (or soy sauce or worcestershire), dried parsley, dried oregano, and fresh basil. you may also want to add spice and acid like vinegar or lemon juice or something but that's up to you.
I make the meat sauce the previous day before I bake the lasagna because it takes like an hour and a half of simmering for the sauce to cook thoroughly until the meat is tender.
I add a slice of butter to the sauce and mix it in on the day i assemble the lasagna just because.

For the cheese filling you can do either the ricotta + egg filling you may have seen or a bechamel-based cheese sauce. No matter what cheese you are using for the cheese filling, i recommend including some parmigiano reggiano in there as well.
And lastly I don't use mozzarella in the filling - only for the very top of the lasagna.

For the sauce do a normal soffritto (onion, carrots, celery), brown your minced meat (my grandma always used half beef half pork) after and then add your choice of tomato sauce/canned tomatoes. For spices: salt, couple bayleaves and basil leaves. Let it simmer for like 2-3 hours.
You gotta also make a bechamel sauce, and put a good amount of sauce on every layer plus some parmesan cheese

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18939289
Pho is hard to compare to ramen, because ramen does not have a beef broth. It is either pork or miso based usually.

On the surface, yes, both are a bone broth with noodles and meat, ramen usually throwing in extra shit for giggles (like corn or bamboo shoots).

Personally, pho is cleaner tasting. It doesn't have the oils that ramen does and it just feels better for lunch. Ramen is always a bit greasy due to the extra oil they put in it. Ramen definitely wins the variety award for all the various toppings and extras you get though: eggs, bamboo shoots, corn, etc. The pork is definitely better than pho beef, because the pork is marinated and so, so good. Same with the marinated egg. Just a fantastic experience.

At the end of the day, pho is the best beef soup and ramen is the best pork soup. They each are heavy hitters of their respective corners.

>It doesn't have the oils that ramen does and it just feels better for lunch.

3 strikes, you are fucking OUT
First, your broth is, quite literally, shit. We pour flavoured tallow (the layer that we skimmed after floating to the top of the broth during long simmer) on top of our bowls. It shines with the layer of the rich fat. My lips will chafe and feel sticky after eating my Pho. And it's completely wrong if they weren't.
Second, properly cooked brisket for Pho, btfo any Ramen Cha Siu, this is from my personal experience with top-tier Pho (my mom's) and top-tier Ramen (top-rated Ramen shops ran by Japanese, both non-chain and chain). This point is closely linked to the first point, because a good broth will enhance the brisket as well. Brisket, cooked properly will be tender, yet springy. Something that Ramen Cha Siu will never achieve. You will have to use another pork cut for that.
Third, again, closely linked to the 1st point, you have never slurped a proper high-quality egg yolk from an indigenous egg, slightly cooked and warmed in a hot bowl of Pho, along with a spoonful of that quality broth. Ramen egg (or ajitsuke tamago) is also my favourite, but when faced with a properly served Pho egg, it simply can not compete.
The problem is that, most Pho restaurants here blow. Fucking disgrace.

Holy shit it's identical, you're just skipping the whole point, which is to make sure there's nothing left over on the fucking utensil.

It's a simple concept: a utensil with a lot of surface area means a lot of area that something like honey will stick do. If you're making something (like a sauce) later that needs some liquid sweetener anyway, you can use water to remove all the excess honey from the utensil (or analogous sticky substance for analogous applicable food) because the honey dissolves easily in water. Thus you get virtually zero wasted honey and an easily cleaned utensil. This should not be fucking controversial, yet everybody is hung up on the idea that as soon as water touches something it becomes "dishwater" like a bunch of fucking 5-year-olds.

Mine has 12 levels.
0-3 - warming, nice for melting fats and slow sauces
3-6 - this is where you cook

12 - quick boil/pre-heat for stainless that can handle it

If it doesn't heat up evenly and it doesn't because cast iron is granular and sucks at heat conductivity, pans can crack due to stress between hot and cold zones.

Main problem with induction is your cookware needs to be flat. Almost every skillet pot or pan after use will warp slighlty and not sit flat giving you uneven cooking and heating. This is why everyone loves gas burners you can use anything on it and is low hassle with good control.

I made schnitzel sandwich, I made a brine, brined the meat for two hours then marinated it in egg and a shit ton of minced garlic and parsley overnight then I mixed flour with cornstarch l, baking soda and oregano and I mixed bread crumbs with oats, seeds and freshly grated parmesan cheese
I coated the meat in flour then egg then crumb mixture
While I fried it I made my own mayonnaise then I made aioli with it
I also made my own pita bread
I stacked the schnitzel on top of the pita bread with dee jhons mustard and aioli then I put some ham on top and provolone cheese and parmesan cheese and I gratinated it in the oven and I fried an egg sunny side and stacked it on top with barbecue sauce as fancy decoration like they do in restaurants
It was part good
Then I had some melon for dessert and it completely blew it away
Just a slice of something that comes from the ground no need to get half my kitchen dirty, no need to go shopping to the butcher and the grocery store and the deli, no need to overspend
No need to waste hours cooking either
Why the fuck am I eating anything else?

I find fake meat morally repugnant. Properly done, regenerative farming is quite good for the environment and results in great living conditions for the animals. All of these plant based products require ever more massive tracts of land for growing corn and soy, which is quite destructive. Tilling up thousands of acres of land releases tons of sequestered CO2 into the environment and destroys natural habitat for plants and animals. It requires far more fuel to be burned, and ever more complicated industrial manufacturing techniques. Over time growing those crops depletes the soil, and requires expensive and dangerous chemical fertilizers and pesticides.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18934408
I eat them once a week, on average. Testicles are a local delicacy (but folklore to me), brains, sweetbread, liver, tripes and kidneys are more regular fare. They look perfectly appetizing to me, when fresh. In winter I add paws, tails, ears, tongues, pressed face. I find plastic packaging utterly disgusting and ads irritate me so much they chase me away.

Turn brains into a brain croquette (absolutely delicious) and I start having problems because I can't check if the brain is fresh any more. Same for sauces of course. Needless to say I make my own bread and most of my pickles/vinegars/tabasco. I buy dairy, wheat, wine, beer, olive oil, fruit&eg and mustard straight from the producer. Herbs and flowers come from my garden and spices from a Michelin star chef who travels the world looking for the best crops.

Minced meat needs to be meat, minced, full stop. The butcher minces the piece I choose in front of my eyes. No salt, no pepper, no breadcrumbs, no 75% porc and 5 % beef. No minced meat that's 82% meat.

Proper produce, minimal manipulation, sauces in support of the product. Autistic heaven.

>>18924203
Traditionally in the US steak was cooked well-done until the 1930's. Because of the Dustbowl (look it up, kids) and rail disruptions it was impossible for the New York steakhouses to get the top-quality beef from Texas and Oklahoma they were used to. The lower quality beef was tough to begin with and some cuts were worse. So the restaurants in New York switched to sirloins as the default and so on.
They also started cooking these leaner cuts medium rare to both take advantage of the lean and to hide the lower quality of the steak itself.
Sauces and such also leaped into use because of this. The UK developed Steak Diane in a similar move to hide the low quality of beef during the worst of teh Depression.
AS the tony nightspots in New York and London adopted these tricks to cover and stretch cheap, low-quality meat it was replicated across a lot of Europe and (especially) the US such that a few generations later the majority of Americans associate 'medium-rare-' with 'high class' to the point they extend it to ridiculous things like hamburgers, massively increasing the risk of food bone pathogens but at least they aren't 'acting lower class', amirite?

There's a reason it's called "well done" and not "overdone". If the meat tastes dry and tough or rubbery then it's overdone, just like it would be with fish or chicken. The point of doing "well done" well is that the cooking is timed precisely to stop when the meat is cooked through. In that sense it arguably requires more skill than to do any other steak preparation, unless you're do it sous vide or something.

tldr: if it's "overdone" it's not "well done". Under, over, over, done.

>>18937646
>It's double the price but not double the size. So no, it doesn't really make sense.
On the Lodge website, the 12" is $30, and the 13.25" is $50. Their most common model is the $10.25", which is regularly $24 and currently marked down to $20. One of the reasons cast iron, in general, is not popular is due to the weight. We can see that the 12", at 7.89 lbs, is 47% heavier than the 10.25" (5.35 lbs), and the 13.25", at 10.5 lbs, is 100% heavier than the 10.25" skillet. So based on weight, there is TWICE the iron in the 13.25 inch skillet as in the 10.25 inch skillet--you might have had some inkling of this if you understood the difference between diameter and area of a circle.

Based on material alone, the regular price of the 10.25" being half of the 13.25" makes sense. However, you'd be stupid if you thought that was the only factor. Because the 10.25" is more popular, more stores are going to order them reliably. Lodge can make more of them, without worrying if they will sell and receive a return on their investment. It's the one model that they know they won't have leftover stock at the end of the year; therefore, they can afford to sell them with thinner margins. Hence the $20 price right now.

So basically, you're a complete idiot and you should feel bad about it.

posts.com:
>>18936341
Not how it works. No idea where that idea comes from because it always gets brought up but it's not true. Try it and you will see.

Crystal clear ice is less about the water and more about how it's frozen. Commercial machines use a freezing plate and circulation to make the freezing process directional from the bottom up. The source of cloudiness is tiny bubbles. The directional freezing pushes the bubbles up as it goes.

You can replicate something like this in a decent sized chest freezer and a plastic cooler with the top off. Since this is more of a top down freeze it creates a block that is mostly glass-clear but has a bottom region of intensely cloudy ice that can be easily chopped off

The resulting ice is not only cool looking but substantially denser than normal ice, making it last longer in a drink or on a centerpiece as a sculpture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937686
>Why not just boil them?
That is what I normally do. They have a somewhat unpleasant smell, and when I blanched them it seemed like it cleaned that away, but I don't really want to fuck up another batch by testing it out.
Roasting is supposed to add flavor.

>And why do people eat animal feet?
In broths the feet are all bones and tendons, which break down into collagen/gelatin. It's miraculous for stomach pain. It also improves the mouth feel. It's more dense than water and kind of silky. Apparently all nice ramen restaurants use some feet in their broths because of this.

Outside of broths, fried feet are popular in some parts of asia.

>>18938182
For pasta I use 2 eggs per 1 cup of dough, makes me 3 portions, which really can feed 2 people, my op is one portion. Sometimes I do 2 cups and use 4 eggs for 6 portions, I've never bothered with more because 6 portions means I'm eating pasta all week.

To form, make a mound of flour, then starting from the center, create a well, have fingers together pointing down in like a wedge, spiral outwards to create basically a bowl of flour. Make sure walls are high and not to thin as you will break your eggs into this flour bowl.
Beat the eggs into an even consistency, and slowly incorporate flour, taking bits from the walls evenly, once egg flour mixture is becoming thick, use a dough scrapper to fold in the walls a cut into the thickened eggs. Do this for all of the walks and it should become a shaggy dough.
Begin to fold the dough, draw one part away and fold back on itself, this is to incorporate air into the dough, do this until the dough has fully come together, it should be a yellow color at this point, knead until smooth and portion

Whichever pasta you want them make, roll the portioned dough balls pretty much paper thin, it will double in size after boiling so keep that in mind. If you fold up your dough to cut ribbons like I did, be sure to lightly flour both sides to prevent it from mushing together. Flour the knife too to keep it from sticking.

Culinary history be like
>Mostly eaten by peasants and the infirm up through the 16th century, this rustic dish was usually prepared with the previous day's bread and foraged dirt melon, which was commonly found in the area. Typically regarded only as animal feed, physicians of the time cited dirt melon as the cause of gout, dysentery, and chlamydia. In 1621, Duke Mathéo Frédéric Subercaseaux orders dirt melon to be eradicated from Europe. The dish is no longer eaten for over a century until the chef of King George III prepares it for his luncheon with a Transylvanian baron. The price for dirt melon becomes popular with the British upper crust and goes by the now common name Pomme de Saint-Georges. La pomme de Saint-Georges remains popular in high end cuisine to this day, commanding prices upwards of $325 per gram.

Culinary science be like
>Eaten almost exclusively by royalty for centuries, Asstree Bark was an extremely difficult crop to grow and maintain, requiring the blood of one adult human per day and only naturally occurring in modern day Singapore. By the 18th century, it was estimated over 30 million people had been killed for Asstree rearing. By 1892, Asstree production had been banned in every country after several civil wars in multiple countries over Asstree orchard disputes and ethical concerns. In 1952, American scientist Norville Johnson isolates the flavor compound of Asstree bark, allowing mass production of the flavoring for pennies. Asstree is now a popular flavor of ice cream and shampoo scent.

not OP but do the math

1 cup of whole milk contains 8g of fat.
1 tbsp of butter is 14g which includes 11g of fat, thus butter is approximately 80% fat.
16 cups in a gallon.
(8g / 0.8) x 16 = 160g or 5.64 ounces of butter.

Not quite a half pound though.

>>18919002
Reminder that 95% of scotch distilleries are owned by multi-national corporations, import barley from countries overseas such as Turkey and Egypt, do the malting offsite, buy peat from other regions of Britain, use lab-created yeast for their mash, use barrels made from American or Spanish wood, and add caramel coloring to the final product.

The only thing authentic about any particular region or scotch distillery is the water or copper stills, both of which could hardly be said to contribute any unique flavor profile to the scotch over any other distillery.

The only thing that gives a scotch an authentically unique flavor profile that is not imported from elsewhere is the process by which the components are put together, i.e. smoked peat, grain ratios, etc. This is a process, which has nothing to do with utilizing the resources of the terroir.

All of this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the over-insistence that each distillery possesses a unique terroir. French wine for example has much stricter requirements for the definition of something like Champagne. If the grapes don't come from Champagne, it is not Champagne.

You are buying a good that is being sold to you as a goodgoy lifestyle product, like a bottle of Armani cologne. There is nothing uniquely Scottish to a bottle of scotch whisky in 2023. It is a globohomo product that is purposefully aimed toward the same soijaks who buy Bespoke Post and Beard Oil and wax philosophic dilletantism about the "delicious" and "complex" smokey peat flavor of Islay malts while looking down their noses at Speyside drinkers, pretending that Don Draper is "literally me" not knowing they're all part of the same retarded, consoomerist goycattle, drinking the epitome of a fake product.

LVMH (French):
Ardbeg, Glenmorangie

Diageo (English):
Johnnier Walker, Talisker, Lagavulin, Caol Ila

Beam Suntory (Japan):
Laphroaig, Ardmore, Auchentoshan, Bowmore

Pernod Ricard (France):
Aberlour, Strathclyde, Glenlivet, Scapa, Lomond, Chivas

Bruichladdich, Octomore, Port Charlotte

Bunnahabhain

Dalmore, Jura

That enough for you, faggot? Wow, sure are a lot of authentically, wholly-owned Scottish companies in that list, huh? And you really believe international mega-corporations aren't going to cut corners to fulfill the obligation to their shareholders?

The majority of barley is imported through Port Ellen (owned by Diageo), 80-90% of which is foreign import. It is germinated and malted onsite at Port Ellen. As for the barrels, check the websites of any scotch brands and find me a single one not made with American, Spanish or French oak, I dare you. Caramel coloring is not only a reality of scotch production but actually *sanctioned* by the British government - check the regulations yourself. That authentic peat flavor you bloviate about endlessly can comes from Aberdeenshire - the literal other side of the country from Islay. Considering the distribution of peat worldwide, it would be of no surprise to me if this was imported from Eastern Europe as well.

So that whittles down the contribution of individual distilleries to their copper stills, their water and their process.

Global ownership isn't relevant.
The corners aren't particularly cut because there are non foreign owned distilleries to compete against (if anything the big multi nationals are competing more heavily on price and value which is good for the consumer).
There is a distinct taste to the peat sourced through Port Ellen, we don't really care about it's origin.
Used American Oak is the hallmark of scotch whisky. Everyone is expecting this and it's basically required.
Caramel colouring is overrated as a flaw. It doesn't really effect flavour.
Stills are hugely relevant.
Marketing isn't. We're all whisky nerd here, so cut the bullshit and taste some whisky. Scotch isn't bad because you're angry about politics or terroir.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937690
I am in the process of doing this right now. My chums and I have something of a club house and we are constantly running out of club soda for cocktails. A few weeks ago we were tinkering with a broken kegarator and realized we could likely fix it with a 30 dollar main board. So a Chinese board, a couple good used corny kegs, and some internet research about water mineralization and we are off. The first batch is actually going to be ready tomorrow, so we will see.

This system holds 10 gallons at a time and probably only makes sense in our specific circumstance, that being a private hangout that gets occasional bar like crowds.

It's also economically debatable. The kegerator we used was basically free since we fixed a broken one, but one of this size would be 800 bucks new, and even a smaller single keg unit used in not the greatest condition would be several hundred bucks. You can also Adapt a normal fridge but that still adds up to a couple hundred bucks. Our project was equal parts hobby project and hyper-first world convenience seeking. less about actual money savings, but it will likely pay for its self eventually if everything works out.

Some autist made a spreadsheet that does all the chemistry math for mineralization so it's not difficult.

I am going for a crisp, large bubble, exceptionally carbonated water with sodium levels and mineral bill that is about halfway between Perrier and Topo Chico but I won't really know if it's a winner until I get a taste this weekend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18939590
Very, very based. You're going the extra based route and using distilled or RO water and remineralizing, but if you felt like it they sell an auto refilling corny keg top. I have one it works quite well, but unfortunately I can't get as high of a carbonation as I'd like because I have a well and you get reveese flow if your pressure is too high.

There's also getting a 2.5 gallon corny and a small co2 tank that will all fit nicely in a normal fridge, but you gotta really love sparkling to give up even that much space.

I built a 5 tap kegerator out of an old fridge, and a bunch of cheap/free sanke fittings I got from an auction. I even have a box that mixes nitrogen and co2 in both lager/ale and nitro stout ratios. It's pretty sweet.

Food carts in Portland are excellent. While in most cities like LA and NYC people brag about going to expensive or exclusive places, people in Portland brag about going to the cheapest, most dirty, hole in the wall and least known places, allowing the food cart industry to thrive. >>18934819
The better quality your avocado, the simpler and more fresh your guac should be. In essence: avocado, salt, citrus or light acid, and cilantro (or parsley or similar if your guest hates it).

If your avocado is less fresh, or you're using a more local recipe, then you can roast your garlic, chilies, and (if using) tomatoes/tomatilloes before adding, which adds complexity and helps cover up any funkiness that someone might detect in older avocados. I make guac like this with brown clearance avocados all the time and people never notice that -- they more take notice that the ingredients are whole and grilled.

posts.com:
Here's how I cook black beans for mexican-style dishes:
>finely dice onion, garlic, some poblano pepper
>sweat the onion and pepper in oil until fragrant, then add in the garlic
>before the garlic burns, add in cumin seed, chili powder, paprika and a bay leaf or two, toast in the oil for 30 seconds or so
>strain the beans of its canning liquid, add to the pan, then add like half a cup or so of chicken stock
>allow the beans to come up to a simmer, simmer until the stock reduces the beans thicken it and become tender, add more stock if it gets too thick
>when the optimal texture has been reached, season to taste with salt, pepper, and the teensy splash of apple cider vinegar

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.com:
I like making pepperoni rolls. They are a good snack/meal to take with you when you go hiking/on an outing, especially if you won't have access to a microwave, although you certainly can warm them up.

I started with a bit of a pre-ferment, just some bread flour, yeast, and water in a quart plastic container, let that bubble up for a few hours.

Sifted maybe 4 parts bread flour to 1 part whole wheat flour into my stand mixer. Added 2 sticks melted, cooled butter. Usually I use little bits of butter but I am trying something different this time. 4 eggs, salt, maple syrup (or you could use sugar but often they are a little sweet- in my mind you want a contrast between a slightly sweet dough and a rather tart tomato sauce in the roll).
I didn't need to add any additional water between the moisture from the butter, pre-ferment, and eggs.

I'm making a tomato sauce with 4 cans whole tomatoes, hand-crushed a bit, but you don't strictly need to, the whole thing gets stick-blendered at the end. Vodka, olive oil, salt, pepper, cayenne pepper, lots of dried basil and oregano, maple syrup, apple cider vinegar (I want it sorta tart and a little sweet), 2 diced onions, and a whole lotta grated garlic (1 head of garlic or so).

The tomato sauce slow-bakes uncovered in the oven at 300F for 3-4 hours until done.
The dough is gonna rise in the fridge probably for about 2 days.
Then just divide the dough into balls, roll it out, not too-too thin and stuff it with tomato sauce, grated mozz cheese, and of course some thick cut pepperoni slices and bake it until golden brown (err on the side of baking a bit more than less). I am aware it is not really traditional to include tomato sauce in pepperoni rolls, but I like it better that way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm intrigued. How long do these last once baked? You just bake them, let them cool and take them with you, or is there some other storage?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18938762
I add calcium propionate, which is an anti-spoilage agent, so they should be fine no matter what for a day or two. I keep them in a cooler with ice when traveling but honestly I think pepperoni rolls would be fine for a few days without spoiling if cooked, especially if you individually wrap them as I do.

I followed the YouTube instructions. Indians roast everything in ghee, pretty much. You don't need much, a table spoon or two
Chop dates with knife (fresh dates,"first fruit is jeetspeak for nuts)

>>18938581
If you take a sharp knife and slice around the bone on the bottom of the chicken leg, you can pull the bottom skin and cartilage off. This also severs the main tendon. At this point you can pull the rest of the skin off if you like, or leave it. What will remain is only the top cartilage and the needle bone inside which are both difficult to remove.

Here is a video, if you just want to remove the meat: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dzJN6wibTf0

I prefer to trim the bottom and cook bone-in, if you do so properly it's no big deal to pull the cooked meat off.

Chili
>brown a pound of ground beef in big pot with about a spoonful of oil on medium/low heat, break up with spatula as soon as it hits the pot
>add a chopped white or yellow onion as beef cooks
>add a little oregano, chili powder, and garlic powder
>add 32oz or so of chicken or beef stock, a big can of diced tomatoes (don’t drain), a couple cans of kidney/pinto beans, a big spoonful of tomato paste, a spoonful of worcestershire sauce, and some hot sauce
>cook on low heat so it bubbles just a little bit for at least 30-45 minutes
>goes well with lots of carbs, could do bread, baked potatoes, etc. I like to make cornbread to go with chili, a box mix is a fine place to start

posts.com:
>>18939180
Realistically, you are a cooklet. So we need to wean you off the goyslop and ease you into cooking from scratch.

First, you need to go to the isle that has premixes OP. You are going to pickup various packets of dry mixes with rice/risotto/pasta. These are going to be your practice material. Get some milk and butter to go with them, and maybe some meatballs from the freezer section. These packets are 1 pot meals, so get a pot from the store while you are there, and a wooden spoon/spatula.

Now, at home, fire up your range, medium burner, and put the pot on. Or zippy zap the coil to warm it up, whatever. Butter pat, in. Follow the meal instructions and put in water and milk in the ratio prescribed. Wait for it to boil. Add mix packet. Reduce heat, and stir for X minutes (7 - 10 depending on what it says). Put in bowl when done.

Congratulations, you are now a level 1 cook. You can follow basic directions and make a "meal".

Next time, you add the frozen meatballs at the start to the dish. Now instead of just noodles and sauce, you have a strogenoff. Or whatever you want. Start learning creativity here. This is basic meal assembly skills here.

For level 2: start swapping ingredients. Learn what using alcohol does to the dish. Add things and seasonings to the mix; use the whole spice rack. This will give you a standard to keep so you can experience the effect ingredients have on a dish. Swap sherry for some of the water. Add broccoli. Add different meats. Add cheese at the end. Learn how ingredients change the process. Once you have experimented and learned all sorts of things, it is time for level 3.

Level 3: do it all from scratch. Your goal here is to recreate these packet meals from scratch: that means getting the rice, the onions, the garlic, the broccoli, the pasta, etc. from the market and doing all the processing yourself. From here you will need to learn knife work and start learning ingredient qualities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18939654
This is going to be the quickest and most effective way to learn a lot of shit fast. The meals are super fast, like done in 15-20 min, and they are standardized & satisfying, so they will taste the same every time and be worth doing. This lets you practice with individual components and learn shit: is oil better than butter, what is my preferred salt level, what combination of things do I like, what seasonings are good, how do cream and cheese work, how does a sauce come together. And if you fuck up you literally only lose like 2 dollars. Start over and do it again, no tears shed.

Once you are familiar with food, its prep and what things actually do, you can move on to real recipes from scratch. This way you won't waste expensive cuts of meat and fish.

Oh, and curry is a great way to move off of packet based meals into near from scratch cooking. You will need to brown meat for that, and it involves basic chopping and veggie prep. The curry brick lets you avoid the seasoning process and roux production.

Once you get your training wheels off, you then move into all the from-scratch recipes and work your way up the complexity tree: start simple with stews, pasta, basic meals. Then get into things that take hours to make. Then fall down the rabbit hole that is baking. Or fall down the BBQ rabbit hole. All of this is plenty well documented in cooking youtube and food channels.

The key with learning how to cook is to learn the hows and whys.
If you like reading, read Salt, Fat, Acid, and Heat.
The hot pocket eaters will tell you that's a meme. But learning food theory will do you much better than years of trial and error of following recipes.

>>18932250
>1:3 ratio of yellow turnip to kennebec (any non waxy potato is kosher) iirc i did 1kg of potatoes and had a 300g turnip
>250ml of heavy cream
>5 garlic cloves minced/microplaned
>tablespoon of kosher salt
>tsp of white pepper
>tsp of black pepper
>tbsp of tallow/butter/lard
>heat cream, minced/planed garlic salt, pep, tallow until almost boiling and transfer to SS bowl
>peel pots and turnups and mandoline/meat slicer/cut as thin as possible like ⅛" into bowl of hot cream
>toss a few times to evenly distribute seasonsings
>either layer in a cake pan of whatever size or layer in a 4" ring mold with foil on the bottom
>if using cake pan fill another full of hot water with a foil on the bottom and weigh down the potato mixture and bake at 400f until fork tender

>ideally fill cake pan 1/3-1/2 at max cause cream boil over, put a baking tray below your cake pans
>if using ring molds use an empty soup can that fits and fill with beans or use a all metal olmypic weight to weigh the can down
>once fork tender after like 30-40 mins unmold/un weigh and bake at 450f for 5 mins to crisp up
thats aboot it

It tastes pretty good, but it's mostly just a fun challenge I like to mess with. Sometimes I wish I had some lab equipment...

Tilapia's nutrition isn't as great as the benefits touted by the oily fish including the salmonids, but it's still a fish that's a better source of omega 3s than other meats, whether wild or farmed.

Regarding cooking, I agree that it's a pretty tasteless white fish, but if you just need that texture then there are plenty of recipes for which it can be essential.

The most basic way I know of to prepare bland cheap tilapia filets is to rub both sides generously with ground cumin and fry that up in like 2 T of oil. Cumin is quite cheap in the bulk containers and will act as both flavoring and similar to flouring. Salt and pepper to serve, plus lemon and maybe olive oil to taste is as simple as it gets. Look also for filets with a good bit of skin or ask the fish dude to leave the skin on when they scale it -- in the West they remove the skin from a lot of the pre-cut filets, and the skin being mostly fat will add a lot of flavor (that's why they love it in Asia).

>>18936399
For thicker cut filet mignons you should reverse sear.

preheat oven to 225, season with only salt.
Use a thermometer placed in the center of the steak, and wait until it reaches 125-129 internal.

Pull steaks, add generous amount of oil to thick cast iron or carbon steel pan.
Max heat.
Wait until oil starts smoking
Add steaks, start timer, and flip every 15 seconds until your timer reaches 2 minutes.

Season with cracked pepper. Enjoy.

As for the pan sauce, I like the classic brown sauce/gravy. Deglaze your steak pan as your steaks cool off with half a shallot, add some compound garlic/thyme/rosemary butter, about a tablespoon of tomato paste, then hit it with 1 part red wine and 2 parts beef stock and season. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18936399
>remove the steak from the fridge at least half an hour before cooking it (this is a bit controversial, but in my experience it helps the steak cook more evenly)
>also season in advance with salt and pepper, so that the juices pulled out by salt can get reabsorbed in the meantime
>heat a pan (better if cast iron, carbon steel or stainless steel) until it's very hot, but not scorching hot
>add a thin but uniform layer of oil with a high smoke point (avocato, groundnut, canola...)
>pat the steak dry with a paper towel
>as soon as the oil starts smoking, place the steak in the pan
>flip every minute or so
>after a few minutes, check the temperature with a probe thermometer (buy one, they are very cheap these days)
>remove when the temperature is about to reach your desired doneness (keep in consideration that it will raise by a few degrees even after removing it from the heat)
>let it rest for 5-10 minutes
>cut and serve
